Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 42, YÄma Heaven, Part 28
At that time, the king of geese said to the heavenly beings:
You should always listen to the Dharma and not be negligent. You should befriend those who can benefit others and go to them to listen to the Dharma.
After hearing the true Dharma, out of respect and reverence, this person's wholesome mind will lead to nirvana and the exhaustion of defilements and great bliss.
There are two kinds of people who give rise to the merit of Brahma:
The first is to observe and uphold well;
The second is to seek the exhaustion of defilements.
There are two more kinds:
The first is to always expound the Dharma;

The second is to always listen to the Dharma.ğŸ”½Such Dharma teachers are like parents. They expound the Dharma for people, enabling them to escape from birth and death and attain the ultimate wholesome Dharma.
Such Dharma teachers are like parents. Those who expound the Dharma give the Dharma as a gift.
The benefactor of the Dharma causes others to hear the Dharma. Having heard the Dharma, their minds attain purity and they respectfully revere it.
Those who listen to the Dharma attain thirty-two merits.
What are the thirty-two?

The Dharma master expounds the Dharma to the listeners, like parents to their children, like a bridge in the midst of birth and death. Namely, hearing what has not been heard, and upon hearing it, becoming aware; having become aware, contemplating it; having contemplated it, then practicing and entering it;
having practiced, then able to abide in it and establish others in it, contemplating it together with them, their minds unmoved by misfortune and distress;
being able to plant wholesome roots where wholesome roots have not been planted, contemplating the supremacy of the wholesome roots that have been planted;
causing those whose faculties are ripe to attain liberation, causing those with wrong views to enter into right views;
if unwholesome thoughts arise, being able to eliminate them, increasing wholesome thoughts, eliminating unwholesome causes and conditions, and practicing diligently;
They associate with good people and avoid stinginess and flattery;
They make offerings to their parents, believe in the fruits of karma, and accumulate the karma for a long life;
They are praised by worldly people, protected by the gods, accomplish what they think, and attain the happiness of the Dharma;
They are free from laziness and give rise to diligent effort;
They know gratitude and repay kindness;
They always cultivate mindfulness of death;
At the time of death, their minds are free from regret and remorse, and they will ultimately attain nirvana.
These are the thirty-two merits of listening to the Dharma.
The Dharma teacher is like parents, teaching people the ultimate benefits of the Dharma, speaking without a defiled mind, and benefiting sentient beings with a pure mind, penetrating wisdom.
Having heard this Dharma, they are benefited like the Buddha, and attain liberation within birth and death.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Those who hear the Dharma, from beginningless time, have been transmigrating in birth and death, never hearing the Dharma. Having first heard it from the Dharma teacher, they give rise to a rare mind, like a congenitally blind person whose eyes are opened by a skilled doctor, and who sees various forms in the world that he has never seen before. Having seen them, he is delighted.

In the same way, sentient beings, from beginningless time, have been transmigrating in birth and death, blinded by the power of delusion. Having heard the true Dharma, they plant various wholesome roots in the stage of enlightenment, and see the four noble truths that they have never heard before, the light of the meaning of the sutras. They are delighted, like a congenitally blind person who is delighted to see forms. Seeing the stage of enlightenment, their minds give rise to joy, also like this.
This is called the first merit of hearing the Dharma.
Next, the second merit of hearing the Dharma.
Because of hearing the Dharma, one contemplates in one's mind:
What is the meaning of the Dharma?
If one does not understand by oneself, one asks others:
What is the meaning of such a Dharma?
Those who hear the Dharma hear it from others, and then contemplate it themselves. By contemplating, they cultivate and increase it.

Because of the meaning of the Dharma, they are in accord with each other before and after, and wholeheartedly uphold it. They repeatedly contemplate the meaning, and because of contemplation, their minds are joyful.
In this way, according to what they contemplate, they remember and contemplate, and penetrate the profound meaning.
This is the second merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, the third merit of hearing the Dharma is:
According to the Dharma one hears, after hearing it one contemplates:
What is the meaning of such a teaching?
What is the cause and condition for such a teaching?
Such a teaching is expounded in order to subdue sentient beings.
Moreover, one contemplates together with those of the same mind and conduct, and by contemplating before and after, one attains great benefit and ultimately attains nirvana.
This is called the third merit of listening to the Dharma.
Next, the fourth merit of listening to the Dharma.
Contemplating the meaning of the Dharma that is taught before and after, one understands and accepts it.
One who understands and accepts it is called one who understands the meaning as it is taught.
One should practice with the three wholesome actions of body, speech, and mind, cultivate and increase them, and accept the teaching of the Dharma.

With a pure mind, having accepted and upheld it, contemplate each phrase, seek its causes and conditions, and according to what one contemplates, one will attain the meaning that has never been heard.

Because of attaining the meaning, one will be able to extinguish all afflictions and fetters, and be able to accept immeasurable merits, precepts, giving, and wisdom, because of the supremacy of the profound mind, precepts, giving, and wisdom.
This is called the fourth merit of listening to the Dharma. One should happily practice and cultivate it, increasing and expanding it.
Next, the fifth merit of listening to the Dharma.
The three types of activities of good listening and good embracing, cultivating oneself firmly, and peacefully abiding in the Dharma when hearing it.
If Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, or laypeople say that a certain good man abides in the true Dharma and practices as taught,

such practice can enable one to know one's own abiding and embrace the Dharma. According to one's abiding, one can extinguish the births and deaths of hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of nayutas of kalpas, and can extinguish the sufferings of immeasurable hundreds of thousands of millions of hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
This is called the great merit and virtue of hearing the Dharma. Cultivating and being close to it brings much benefit.
The expounder of the Dharma shows people nirvÄá¹‡a, like the World-Honored Buddha, enabling them to abide in the Dharma.
This is the fifth merit of hearing the Dharma, due to listening to the true Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the merits of the sixth merit of hearing the Dharma?

Namely, abiding in the Dharma oneself, establishing others to become Dharma vessels, causing them to detest saá¹ƒsÄra, showing them the place of peace and tranquility, speaking of suffering, its origin, cessation, oneself and others both generating merit and virtue, benefiting others, attaining great merit, increasing the Dharma heard more and more, and extinguishing afflictions accordingly, also like this. Because afflictions are extinguished, one attains nirvÄá¹‡a.
Attaining this merit by hearing the true Dharma is called the sixth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the merits of the seventh merit of hearing the Dharma, cultivating and increasing?
Namely, if one encounters decline and affliction, one's mind does not retreat.

Because of hearing about karmic retribution, even if one encounters decline and affliction, one's mind does not become depressed, one does not create evil karma, one does not speak evil words, one does not think evil thoughts, and one does not destroy one's courage.
This is called the seventh merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is the eighth merit of hearing the Dharma?

Either seeing others or knowing others come to request the Dharma, either requesting to hear the Dharma, or requesting precepts, or requesting wisdom, being free from arrogance and explaining it for them, according to what is said, various distinctions are made, making it easy to understand.
This is called the eighth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is the ninth merit of hearing the Dharma?
Those who hear the true Dharma plant the seeds of good roots, just as in a rice field, the dikes are not damaged, and clear water is released, and the sprouts grow;
Going to the Dharma master's place to listen to the true Dharma, planting the seeds of goodness in the field of the ears and the dikes of the mind, it is also like this.
When it comes to maturity, many fruits are harvested, saving from the hunger and hardship of the evil fears of the hells, hungry ghosts, and animals.
Because of saving the three evil destinies, all suffering is eliminated.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Abiding in the wilderness, they are liberated from all fears and enter the unsurpassed state of tranquility.
Because of expounding the Dharma, they attain nirvana.

Those who expound the Dharma are like the World-Honored One. Therefore, the merit of listening to the Dharma is the foremost in escaping from birth and death. One should always be close to them, single-mindedly listen to the Dharma, and practice after hearing it.
This is called the ninth merit of listening to the Dharma.
What is the tenth merit of listening to the Dharma?
Having already planted the seeds of listening to the Dharma, one should protect and uphold them, causing them to mature.
If a person listens to the Dharma, the seeds of good roots will always be accomplished through constant practice.
It is like planting rice seeds in a paddy field at the right time, and when the sun shines on them, they will ripen when the time comes.
The person who listens to the Dharma plants various good roots, and with the sun of wisdom, they will be accomplished as well.
For these reasons, one should always go to the place where the Dharma is being taught to listen and receive the true Dharma.
This is called the tenth merit of listening to the Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the merits of the eleventh merit of listening to the Dharma that are accomplished in this way?
With the wholesome roots of the mind, one always goes to the Dharma assembly to listen to and receive the true Dharma, and contemplates and embraces it.
For these reasons, one's mind becomes subdued, able to extinguish afflictions. Because the afflictions are exhausted, one attains liberation.
Because of liberation, one becomes disgusted with conditioned phenomena and should think like this:
My births are exhausted, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, I will not undergo another existence.
All of this is due to the merit of listening to the Dharma. Therefore, one should always listen to the true Dharma.
This is called the eleventh merit of listening to the Dharma.
Furthermore, the twelfth merit of listening to the Dharma has a different skillful means, which is a great merit and the cause of liberation.
What are the merits?
Namely, causing those with wrong views to enter the correct view.
From beginningless [time] revolving in the cycle of birth and death, hearing evil teachings, accepting wrong views, due to wrong views, falling into hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.

If hearing the correct Dharma, delighting in learning and practicing, cultivating to increase and expand, able to abandon wrong views, practicing the correct Dharma, increasing correct wisdom, attaining the supreme bliss - the bliss of non-deception.
By listening to the Dharma, cultivating and increasing.
This is called the twelfth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the merits of the thirteenth merit of hearing the Dharma, cultivating and increasing?
Namely, if giving rise to even a little unwholesome thought, able to eliminate and cut it off.
If giving rise to sensual desire, cultivating the contemplation of impurity to eliminate it.
If giving rise to anger, cultivating the contemplation of loving-kindness.
If there is a deluded thought, one should contemplate the twelve links of dependent origination to eliminate it.
By listening to the Dharma, one knows the antidotal Dharma, not by not listening to the Dharma.
By listening to the Dharma, one can eliminate even such subtle unwholesome thoughts, let alone the afflictions. Therefore, listening to the Dharma is a great merit.
This is called the thirteenth merit of listening to the Dharma.
Next, the fourteenth merit of listening to the Dharma.
By listening to the Dharma, one can eliminate unwholesome thoughts, just as sunlight eliminates darkness.
Wisdom is also like this, able to eliminate all the darkness of unwholesomeness, causing the Dharma to increase and afflictions to decrease.
Apart from listening to the true Dharma, one cannot eliminate them.
This is the fourteenth merit of listening to the Dharma.
Next, the fifteenth merit of listening to the Dharma is being able to cause wholesome thoughts to increase.
By the power of the merit of hearing the Dharma, not only does one eliminate unwholesome thoughts, but wholesome thoughts increase. Because wholesome thoughts increase, one attains wisdom.
It is like a small fire placed in grass and trees, which grows due to the wind.
The arising of a small wholesome root is also like this. Because of wisdom, it can grow.

If one hears the true Dharma and listens to its meaning, giving rise to a single thought of goodness, one can eliminate the birth and death of countless hundreds of thousands of kalpas and prevent it from arising again.
Knowing that the merit of hearing the Dharma is like this, one should diligently listen to the Dharma. There is no other Dharma that can provide such protection.
Because of hearing the Dharma, one becomes a great donor and practices giving.
Because of hearing the Dharma, one abandons what is contrary to the Dharma.
Because of hearing the Dharma, one attains wisdom.
Having observed that the merit of listening to the Dharma can give rise to birth and death, one should diligently listen to the true Dharma to the end of one's life.
Listening to the Dharma in this way is the foremost savior, the foremost refuge, able to escape the ocean of existence.
This is called the fifteenth merit of listening to the Dharma.
What is the sixteenth merit of listening to the Dharma?
It is said that one is able to avoid unwholesome conditions.
If unwholesome conditions arise, one should contemplate the fear of the evil destinies.
The wise, having contemplated, abandon them, fearing birth and death.
If unwholesome conditions arise, one should avoid them and not engage in them;
In order to prevent their arising, one should diligently practice and uphold the precepts and wisdom.
If greedy thoughts arise, one should practice giving;
If stingy thoughts arise, one should eliminate them without attachment.
With a mind of wisdom, one should destroy ignorance;
With true insight, one should eliminate unwholesome views.ğŸ”½With a mind of right view, one should cut off wrong views;
With right contemplation, one should cut off false discrimination.
If joyful thoughts arise, one should contemplate suffering.
If you give rise to true awareness, you should cultivate the contemplation of emptiness.
If you give rise to the awareness of self, you should contemplate non-self.
This is the true counteraction of conceptual thoughts. If they arise from causes and conditions, you should distance yourself from them;
If they are subtle, coarse, or middling, you should eliminate them.
All unwholesome things that arise from causes and conditions can be avoided by hearing the true Dharma. If one does not hear the Dharma, one will not be able to avoid them.
All those who hear the Dharma are like a safe haven.
This is called the sixteenth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What is the seventeenth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is said that a heedless person, by hearing the Dharma, eliminates evil conceptual thoughts and practices heedfulness.
A heedful person is able to control the senses, and all wholesome dharmas will increase.
A heedful person is able to eliminate all unwholesome dharmas. Such a person is not far from nirvana and attains all forms of happiness.
What are the causes and conditions for abandoning negligence?
It is said to be hearing the true Dharma.
Because of hearing the true Dharma, one knows the faults of negligence and is able to stay far away from them.

Because of hearing the true Dharma, one is able to regulate the faculties. Because the five faculties are regulated, one is able to concentrate the mind, increase wholesome thoughts, and extinguish evil thoughts and views. Because of wholesome views, one attains the foremost bliss.
All afflictions have negligence as their root, and likewise, among all wholesome dharmas, the mind of non-negligence is taken as the fundamental.

Because of hearing the true Dharma, one cuts off negligence. Therefore, sentient beings should always single-mindedly listen to and accept the true Dharma. Having heard it, they should practice it, and through practice, it will increase and grow.
This is called the seventeenth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What are the eighteenth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is said that because of hearing the true Dharma, one becomes close to good friends, makes offerings to good people, cherishes and respects them, contemplates and measures them.
Because of associating with good friends, one attains great merit. If one associates with bad friends, one invites many faults.

There is no other Dharma that can lead one to associate with good friends like hearing the true Dharma. Because of hearing the true Dharma, one can associate with good friends. Therefore, the foremost practice is to associate with good friends.
This is called the eighteenth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the nineteenth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is said that because of hearing the true Dharma, one can cut off deceitful and jealous thoughts.
If one associates with good friends, what merits can one attain?
Because of associating with good friends, one attains superior merits, namely, one can cut off deceit and jealousy.
Because of hearing the Dharma, one can truly believe in karma and its fruits.
If there are sentient beings who are deceitful and jealous, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they will fall into evil paths, either as hungry ghosts or as hell beings.

If one has previously engaged in deceit, stinginess, and jealousy a lot, but upon hearing the true Dharma, one is able to abandon them, and having been criticized, one does not engage in them again, and one feels disgust and remorse for what one has done in the past;
seeing others engaging in deceit, one encourages them not to do so, causing them to feel disgust and remorse for what they have done in the past, and causing them to abide in the good path.
By hearing the true Dharma, one attains this merit, which is the most solid in the human and heavenly realms, namely hearing the true Dharma.
This is the nineteenth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Furthermore, what is the twentieth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is said that having heard the Dharma, one makes offerings to one's parents, understands the fruits of karma, and knows the supreme merit field.

The supreme merit field is none other than one's parents. Understanding this through the causes and conditions of the fruits of karma, one is able to make various offerings to one's parents, providing them with bedding, medicine for illness, and other necessary items. According to what one has done to make offerings to one's parents, one is able to give rise to the merit of the Brahmas.
Due to this merit, they will attain nirvana later.

Moreover, by listening to the Dharma and making offerings to their parents, they will be loved by the people and praised by everyone in this present life. After death, they will be reborn in the good destinies and receive heavenly bodies. Due to the power of listening to the Dharma, they will eventually attain nirvana.

Therefore, the wise ones know these merits and, even at the cost of their lives, should always make offerings to the field of merit of their parents, with right conduct and right intention, and respectfully revere them with a single mind.
This is called the twentieth merit of listening to the Dharma.
The twenty-first merit of listening to the Dharma is knowing the fruits of karma.
Knowing the fruits of karma, one does not delight in other teachings. By listening to the true Dharma, one can know the fruits of karma.

If one thinks of unwholesomeness, one knows it is unwholesome thought. If one thinks of wholesomeness in the mind, one knows it is wholesome thought. One truly knows the fruits of karma.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

If the mind thinks of unwholesome dharmas, know that unwholesome thoughts will later lead to unwholesome and unloved consequences, falling into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals. Knowing this, one will not give rise to an unwholesome mind again.
By this unwholesomeness, one definitely knows that one will obtain unloved consequences, falling into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
Because of creating such evil karmic conditions, my body will certainly fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
These three kinds of karma are understood through hearing the true Dharma. Apart from hearing the Dharma, there is no other way to know them.
Therefore, the wise should always listen to the Dharma even at the cost of their lives.
If one always listens to the Dharma and cultivates wholesome karma, one will not create unwholesome karma.
This is called the twenty-first merit of listening to the Dharma.
Furthermore, what are the twenty-second merits of listening to the Dharma?
Namely, the ability to accumulate and increase the karma of long life.

Because of hearing the true Dharma, one believes in the fruits of karma, does not kill, steal, or engage in other such actions, and happily cultivates and increases various wholesome karmas, thus being reborn among gods and humans with an extended lifespan.
Because of happily cultivating and increasing the true Dharma, one attains such merits and an extended lifespan.
Through the causes and conditions of hearing the Dharma, one is reborn among gods and humans.
If reborn in the heavens, one has the longest lifespan among the other gods, enjoying food, play, and the foremost bliss.

Because of hearing the Dharma, if reborn as a human, one possesses various appearances, strength, wealth, longevity, is born in a good country, always practices right views, and because of hearing the true Dharma, happily cultivates and increases it, and will certainly attain liberation from suffering.
If a person is able to listen to the Dharma with a wholesome mind, it is the foremost merit.
For the sake of listening to the Dharma, if one takes a single step, it gives rise to the merit of BrahmÄ.
Those who listen to the true Dharma always practice listening to the Dharma and attain good physical actions;
Having heard it, they read and recite it, attaining good verbal actions;
Having heard it, their minds become pure, attaining good mental actions.

Because those who listen to the Dharma have good actions of the three karmas, they are reborn among gods and humans, experiencing the foremost, most excellent wealth and happiness, with a long lifespan, and ultimately attain nirvana.
All these great merits and virtues are all due to listening to the Dharma, not to anything else. Therefore, hearing the Dharma is the foremost peace and security.
This is called the twenty-second merit of hearing the Dharma.
What are the merits of the twenty-third merit of hearing the Dharma?

It means that those who hear the Dharma are praised by all people. The merits of upholding precepts, being well-versed in learning, taming, and having excellent wisdom are all respected, worshipped, and greeted by people of the world. They speak beautifully and straightforwardly to all people.
Such a person, whose merits are in accord with the Dharma, is always fearful of even the slightest evil;
he is well-known to all, praised by everyone, and if he encounters trouble, many people will come to his rescue.
One who hears the Dharma is praised by the world.
This is called the twenty-third merit of hearing the Dharma.
What is the twenty-fourth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is being protected by the devas.
One who hears the Dharma is in accord with good karma. He practices good physical, verbal, and mental actions. Because of this merit, he is protected by the devas.
Because of this person, many people are at peace;
when this person dies, countless people will lose their benefits.
In order to protect this person, the demons will be diminished and the true Dharma will flourish.
Seeing these causes and conditions, the gods therefore guard day and night, always following behind, and whatever they do is accomplished.
By the power of the gods' grace and by their own good karma, they mutually serve as causes for each other.
The work they do, having already been accomplished, follows the work they do and is cultivated and expanded, and all good karma is accomplished.
In this way, there is benefit in both this and future lives.
In this way, the merit of hearing the Dharma is the foremost treasure of peace and security.
This is called the twenty-fourth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What are the merits of the twenty-fifth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is said that all recollections are accomplished.

This person who practices in accordance with the Dharma and has wisdom, upholds the precepts, gives generously, and has the present karmic retribution. All recollections are accomplished. Whatever they do is accomplished and cannot be stolen.

If what they do is easy to accomplish, they will enjoy it in accordance with the Dharma, free from the five difficulties, with a pure livelihood, not controlled by others. When their body breaks up and their life ends, they will be born in a good realm, in a heavenly body.
This is the twenty-fifth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What is the twenty-sixth merit of hearing the Dharma?
It is called wealth and happiness in accordance with the Dharma.

Those who observe precepts together, whether wealthy or poor, all come to be close to them. Because they observe precepts together, they mutually give to each other. The wealth they obtain is not obtained by harming others or oppressing others, but in accordance with the Dharma. They give to those who practice the Dharma.
The merit of their giving increases more and more, benefiting both this world and the next, bringing happiness in both this world and the next.
Because of hearing the Dharma, they obtain this merit.
This is the twenty-sixth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What is the twenty-seventh merit of hearing the Dharma?
Namely, wisdom and the avoidance of laziness, by listening to the true Dharma and hearing about the faults of laziness.
Because of laziness, one cannot accomplish worldly and transcendent dharmas and meanings.

By listening to the Dharma, one abandons laziness and always diligently applies oneself to all activities, with right mindfulness and non-distraction. By avoiding lazy people, all one's skillful activities are quickly accomplished, done in a timely manner and in accordance with the Dharma, and all are accomplished for the benefit of both this and future lives.
If one avoids laziness and always diligently applies oneself, all one's activities will be brought to completion, and all one's intentions will be accomplished.
If one was originally lazy but, by listening to the true Dharma, knows the faults of laziness and quickly abandons them, like discarding a knife or fire,
because of laziness, one can destroy all worldly activities.
By listening to the faults of laziness, all one's goals and benefits will be accomplished, due to the power of the merit of listening to the true Dharma.
This is called the twenty-seventh merit of listening to the Dharma.ğŸ”½Next, what are the twenty-eighth merits of listening to the Dharma?
What are those merits?ğŸ”½They are called the merits of listening to the Dharma in sequence, giving rise to a mind of gratitude, and knowing the kindness of others.
Because it is said in the true Dharma to repay kindness, one thinks of repaying kindness and knows that by repaying kindness, all friends become firm.
Because of merit, even all enemies are like friends.
If a person has little kindness, always remembers it, knows kindness and repays kindness, he attains great merit.
This is called the twenty-eighth merit of listening to the Dharma.ğŸ”½Next, what are the twenty-ninth merits of listening to the Dharma?
What are those merits?
They are called the merits of practicing mindfulness of death.
The foremost and supreme mindfulness is called mindfulness of death. Because of always being mindful of death, one feels fear. Because of fear, one does not create evil karma.
Even if one sees beautiful forms, one does not think of distinguishing them;
Hearing various pleasant sounds, they do not give rise to thoughts of them;ğŸ”½If they smell various fragrances, they are neither greedy nor attached, nor do they give rise to thoughts of them;
If the tongue experiences tastes, they are neither greedy nor attached, nor do they give rise to thoughts of them;
If the body experiences tactile objects, they are neither greedy nor attached, nor do they give rise to thoughts of them;
If the mind cognizes dharmas, they are neither greedy nor attached, nor do they give rise to thoughts of them, thus severing and transcending this entire net of existence.
Such people, fearing death, contemplate that in the entire world there is nothing solid, that everything is suffering, that everything is devoid of self, and that everything is empty.

Those who truly see this have no attachment in any place, whether among gods or humans, let alone in the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals. They completely sever all hopes within the five realms and attain liberation.
Within all the suffering of birth and death, they no longer delight in it, but fear and detest it.
Because of their detestation, they attain liberation and the wisdom of liberation:
My births are ended, the holy life has been established, what was to be done has been done, and I will not know another existence after this one.

If one is separated from hearing the Dharma, one cannot attain such merits of renunciation as establishing the holy life. Therefore, one should diligently listen to and accept the true Dharma, be close to teachers and elders, make offerings, and listen to the Dharma. The benefits of the present and future lives are as follows: namely, being close to good and virtuous friends and listening to the true Dharma. By means of these two dharmas, one attains peace and security.
This is called the twenty-ninth merit of hearing the Dharma.
Next, what are the merits of the thirtieth merit of hearing the true Dharma?
It is said that because of hearing the Dharma, one has no regrets at the time of death.
Cultivating mindfulness of death, if there is a fault that arises, one is then able to quickly eliminate it.

If the three kinds of defilements - greed, anger, and delusion - arise as the causes and conditions of birth and death, because of mindfulness of death, one is then able to eliminate them.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

By severing the three defilements, one is not born, does not die, does not regress, and does not emerge. There is no other dharma that can sever this dharma. By the power of the merit of hearing the Dharma, one attains such a dharma.
Among all the merits of peace and security, the merit of hearing the Dharma is the primary root.'

At that time, the Bodhisattva Swan King spoke the sutra taught by Kanakamuni for the sake of the heavenly multitudes, in accordance with the true Dharma. This is the thirtieth merit of hearing the Dharma.
What are the merits of the thirty-first merit of hearing the Dharma?
Namely, at the time of death, the mind is without regret.

If one hears the meaning of the true Dharma and practices good deeds, at the time of death the mind will not give rise to regret. According to what one has heard, after hearing it, one recollects and contemplates it.
After contemplating it, one increases the pure mind towards the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.

Because the mind is pure, the blood is then pure. Because the blood is pure, the complexion is pure. Because the body and mind are pure, when one is about to die, one sees the good paths, the lovely heavenly realms with bright light.
Seeing the place of rebirth, one further increases the pure mind, and according to that pure mind, one has faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha, and is reborn in a superior place.

If one performs the karma of the Four Heavenly Kings, due to the pure mind and faith, one is reborn in the second heaven;ğŸ”½if one has the karma of the Thirty-three Celestials, one is reborn in the YÄma Heaven;
